Navigation - Side

Side navigation can be used to provide a one or two level nested navigational structure for sites.

Guidelines

  • Main navigation should be limited to 8 items whenever possible.
  • Labels should be as descriptive as possible; avoid generic labels such as “Products” or “Services”.
  • Organize menu items by order of importance, starting with the most important. If there is a “Contact” screen, it should be last.
  • In situations that require more than 2 navigation levels, contact the UX team for potential solutions.

Documentation

The selection structure is controlled by the classes .active and .active-parent. These class labels are applied to add a green selected bar and expand child elements respectively.

When laying out a page, the side navigation element can be placed inside a .col-md-5 div and the rest of the page content inside a .col-md-19 div. This structure is used on this page and many of the other standards pages.

Modifiers

Class Description
.active add class to a li element to apply active styles
.active-parent add class to parent li element to apply active styles and expand child elements of menu item. The .uxf-side-nav-collapsed class must also be added to the nav.uxf-side-nav element in order to collapse correctly.
.uxf-side-nav-white-bg add class to nav.uxf-side-nav element to apply specific styling for white backgrounds

Javascript

Side navigation can use Bootstrap's affix plugin to apply fixed positioning to the element.

Convert from UXFrame v1 to v2

  1. Remove .clear-bottom from .nav-left
  2. Change div .nav-left to div .nav-uxf-side.panel
  3. Change .selected to .active
  4. Change .selected-parent to .active-parent
  5. Add .nav class to all ul elements
